lines.speaker: u5576
lines.text: When'd you get to town, Raines?

lines.speaker: u5582
lines.text: The other day....

lines.speaker: u5576
lines.text: What for?

lines.speaker: u5582
lines.text: No particular reason. Catch a Laker game. I heard we got Shaquille ...

lines.speaker: u5576
lines.text: Where you been, anyway?

lines.speaker: u5582
lines.text: Just out there. Roaming around. Building up my collection of refrigerator magnets ...

lines.speaker: u5576
lines.text: You seem a little hinked-up ...

lines.speaker: u5582
lines.text: Not at all ...

lines.speaker: u5577
lines.text: Walked like a bastard... Skippin' stones and shit..

lines.speaker: u5584
lines.text: That's a good one, Donny...

lines.speaker: u5577
lines.text: I think so too --

lines.speaker: u5578
lines.text: Okay, okay. What about MAGNUM P.I.?

lines.speaker: u5581
lines.text: Thanks for playing, Freb. That's a gimme ...

lines.speaker: u5579
lines.text: I know...

lines.speaker: u5582
lines.text: We do it. He'll get clear Once and for all

lines.speaker: u5580
lines.text: Okay, then ... I just go to the Marriott and I'm set ...

lines.speaker: u5586
lines.text: You've been pre-booked...

lines.speaker: u5588
lines.text: What are we gonna do -- ?

lines.speaker: u5581
lines.text: Hospital.

lines.speaker: u5588
lines.text: We can't do that, dude --

lines.speaker: u5587
lines.text: Uh ... Randall -- ?

lines.speaker: u5582
lines.text: Excuse me --

lines.speaker: u5586
lines.text: Which way's out, man -- ?

lines.speaker: u5588
lines.text: Shit all looks the same here --

lines.speaker: u5589
lines.text: You think I don't know? You think I like to keep this inside? But I gotta, or he'll kill the miserable bastard and he'll be there for life. It's disgusting what you have to put up with.

lines.speaker: u5598
lines.text: Look at Jeannie's kid.

lines.speaker: u5589
lines.text: What? What happened?

lines.speaker: u5598
lines.text: The oldest one.  He was in an argument. A lousy ten-dollar card game. The kid pulls out a gun. It goes off. The kid gets killed. The grandmother hears it and finds out he's been arrested. She has a heart attack.  She drops dead right on the spot. Now Jeannie's got a husband and son in jail and a mother in the funeral parlor.

lines.speaker: u5589
lines.text: But he was always a bad kid, that one.

lines.speaker: u5598
lines.text: No. Come on. It was the younger one that was the bad one.

lines.speaker: u5590
lines.text: You remember Tommy's shines? The kid was great.  He made mirrors.

lines.speaker: u5602
lines.text: No more shines, Billy.

lines.speaker: u5590
lines.text: Come ooonnn. Tommeeee. We're only kidding. You can't take a joke? Come ooonn.

lines.speaker: u5599
lines.text: I don't need this... You said tonight and now it's not tonight...

lines.speaker: u5591
lines.text: It's okay. I'll make it up.  I promise. Just hurry it up a little. Okay?

lines.speaker: u5599
lines.text: Okay?

lines.speaker: u5592
lines.text: The third store down.

lines.speaker: u5594
lines.text: Jimmy just stood there on the sidewalk. It felt funny. I started walking down the block, but I noticed the stores were empty.

lines.speaker: u5597
lines.text: Don't worry about the schools. We'll take care of the schools.

lines.speaker: u5594
lines.text: I don't want them left back.

lines.speaker: u5597
lines.text: They won't be left back. They'll stay in their grade.

lines.speaker: u5594
lines.text: That's important.

lines.speaker: u5603
lines.text: You want a partner?

lines.speaker: u5600
lines.text: Please?

lines.speaker: u5604
lines.text: No way! You're kiddin'!

lines.speaker: u5606
lines.text: No, he was so hammered that he drove the police cruiser home. Fuckin' lights and everything!

lines.speaker: u5605
lines.text: I've been shit faced for like two weeks.

lines.speaker: u5612
lines.text: Oh great, tell her that! Now she really thinks we're problem drinkers!

lines.speaker: u5606
lines.text: All right, are we gonna have a problem?

lines.speaker: u5607
lines.text: There's no problem. I was just hoping you could give me some insight into the evolution of the market economy in the early colonies. My contention is that prior to the Revolutionary War the economic modalities especially of the southern colonies could most aptly be characterized as agrarian pre- capitalist and...

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: So why do you think I should work for the National Security Agency?

lines.speaker: u5608
lines.text: Well, you'd be working on the cutting edge. You'd be exposed to the kind of technology you couldn't see anywhere else because we've classified it. Super string theory, Chaos Math, Advanced algorithms--

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: Codebreaking.

lines.speaker: u5608
lines.text: That's one aspect of what we do.

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: Come on, that's what you do. You handle more than eighty percent of the intelligence workload. You're seven times the size of the C.I.A.

lines.speaker: u5608
lines.text: That's exactly right, Will. So the question as I see it isn't "why should you work for N.S.A." it's "why shouldn't you?"

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: Why shouldn't I work for the National Security Agency? That's a tough one.

lines.speaker: u5610
lines.text: Where is it touching you?

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: Down there.  And I'm nervous.

lines.speaker: u5610
lines.text: You don't have to be nervous, Will.

lines.speaker: u5620
lines.text: What should I do?

lines.speaker: u5611
lines.text: The boy was here. He came in, sat down and we worked together.

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: So, you finally got a job Morgan?

lines.speaker: u5612
lines.text: Had one, now I'm fucked again.

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: So what do you got, a fuckin' Hyundai engine under there? Can I make it back to my house?

lines.speaker: u5614
lines.text: Well, I can see this is pointless...

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: You're getting defensive...Henry. And hey, cheif--tell the wife, at least. Christ, set her free.

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: See ya.

lines.speaker: u5615
lines.text: Good luck.

lines.speaker: u5621
lines.text: Take care.

lines.speaker: u5616
lines.text: Goodbye.

lines.speaker: u5634
lines.text: Twicet now I've fell for that line. Maybe he needs a thousan' men. So he get's five thousan' there, an' he'll pay fifteen cents a hour. An' you guys'll have to take it 'cause you'll be hungry.  'F he wants to hire men, let him write it out an' say what he's gonna pay. Ast to see his license. He ain't allowed by law to contrack men without a license.

lines.speaker: u5622
lines.text: Joe!

lines.speaker: u5623
lines.text: You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?

lines.speaker: u5638
lines.text: I guess that's what he looked like.

lines.speaker: u5623
lines.text: We just picked him up on the way in. He went away this mornin' when the rate dropped.

lines.speaker: u5638
lines.text: What'd he look like again?

lines.speaker: u5623
lines.text: Short fella. Pale face.

lines.speaker: u5638
lines.text: Was he bruised up this mornin'? About the face?

lines.speaker: u5623
lines.text: I didn't see nothin'.

lines.speaker: u5638
lines.text: Okay. Go on.

lines.speaker: u5624
lines.text: So long.

lines.speaker: u5641
lines.text: Hey, wait a minute. You got change comin'.

lines.speaker: u5626
lines.text: House 25. Number's on the door.

lines.speaker: u5642
lines.text: Okay, mister. Whatcha payin'?

lines.speaker: u5626
lines.text: Two and a half cents.

lines.speaker: u5642
lines.text: Two an' a half! Say, mister, a man can't make his dinner on that.

lines.speaker: u5626
lines.text: Take it or leave it. There's 200 men coming from the South that'll be glad to get it.

lines.speaker: u5642
lines.text: But--but how we gonna eat?

lines.speaker: u5626
lines.text: Look, I didn't set the price. I'm just working here. If you want it, take it. If you don't, turn right around and beat it.

lines.speaker: u5642
lines.text: Which way is House 25?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: Camp site costs a dollar a week, but you can work it out, carrying garbage, keeping the camp clean--stuff like that.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: We'll work it out. What's this committee you talkin' about?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: We got five sanitary units. Each one elects a central committee man. They make the laws, an' what they say goes.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Are you aimin' to tell me that the fellas that run this camp is jus' fellas--campin' here?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: That's the way it is.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: An' you say no cops?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: No cop can come in here without a warrant.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: I can't hardly believe it. Camp I was in once, they burned it out--the deputies an' some of them poolroom fellas.

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: They don't get in here. Sometimes the boys patrol the fences, especially dance nights.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: You got dances too?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: We got the best dances in the county every Saturday night.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Say, who runs this place?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: Government.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Why ain't they more like it?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: *You* find out, I can't.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Anything like work aroun' here?

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: Can't promise you that, but there'll be a licensed agent here tomorrow mornin', if you want to talk to him.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Ma's shore gonna like it here. She ain't been treated decent for a long time.

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: That cut you got?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Crate fell on me.

lines.speaker: u5627
lines.text: Better take care of it. Store manager'll give you some stuff for it in the morning. Goodnight.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Goodnight.

lines.speaker: u5628
lines.text: Can't tell if you hear it or not. You hear it, Tom?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: I hear it. I think they's some guys comin' this way, lots of 'em. We better get outa here.

lines.speaker: u5645
lines.text: Seems like we wasn't never gonna do nothin' but move. I'm so tar'd.

lines.speaker: u5629
lines.text: Women is always tar'd.

lines.speaker: u5645
lines.text: You ain't--you ain't sorry, are you, honey?

lines.speaker: u5629
lines.text: No, but--but you seen that advertisement in the Spicy Western Story magazine. Don't pay nothin'. Jus' send 'em the coupon an' you're a radio expert--nice clean work.

lines.speaker: u5645
lines.text: But we can still do it, honey.

lines.speaker: u5629
lines.text: I ought to done it then--an' not come on any trip like this.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Fella named Spencer sent us--said they was work pickin' peaches.

lines.speaker: u5630
lines.text: Want to work, do you?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Sure do.

lines.speaker: u5630
lines.text: Pull up behind that car.  Okay for this one. Take 'em through.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: What's the matter? What's happened?

lines.speaker: u5630
lines.text: Little trouble up ahead, but you'll get through. Just follow the line.

lines.speaker: u5643
lines.text: Have it your own way, son, but just as sure as you touch my house with that cat I'm gonna blow you plumb to kingdom come.

lines.speaker: u5631
lines.text: You ain't gonna blow nobody nowhere. First place, you'd get hung and you know it. For another, it wouldn't be two days before they'd have another guy here to take my place.

lines.speaker: u5632
lines.text: I never asked you!

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Sure, but you'd a throwed a fit if I hadn't tol' you.

lines.speaker: u5633
lines.text: You people got a lotta nerve.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: What you mean?

lines.speaker: u5633
lines.text: Crossin' the desert in a jalopy like this.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: You been acrost?

lines.speaker: u5633
lines.text: Sure, plenty, but not in no wreck like this.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: If we broke down maybe somebody'd give us a han'.

lines.speaker: u5633
lines.text: Well, maybe. But I'd hate to be doin' it. Takes more nerve than I got.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: It don't take no nerve to do somep'n when there ain't nothin' else you can do.

lines.speaker: u5635
lines.text: An' the nex' thing you know you'll be out, because they got it all figgered down to a T--until the harvest is in you're a *migrant* worker--afterwards, just a bum.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Five they're a-gettin' now, an' that's all they're int'rested in. I know exackly what Pa'd say. He'd jus' say it wasn't none a his business.

lines.speaker: u5636
lines.text: I could break up some bresh if you want me, ma'am.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: You want to get ast to eat, hunh?

lines.speaker: u5636
lines.text: Yes, ma'am.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: Didn' you have no breakfast?

lines.speaker: u5636
lines.text: No, ma'am. They ain't no work hereabouts. Pa's in tryin' to sell some stuff to get gas so's we can get along.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: Didn' none of these have no breakfast?

lines.speaker: u5637
lines.text: *Ain't* a-goin'... ain't a-goin'...

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: 'S all right, Grampa. You just kind a tar'd, that's all. Somebody fix a pallet.

lines.speaker: u5638
lines.text: Where you think you're going?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Thought I'd take a walk. Any law against it?

lines.speaker: u5638
lines.text: Well, you just turn around and walk the other way.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: You mean I can't even get outa here?

lines.speaker: u5638
lines.text: Not tonight you can't. Want to walk back?--or you want me to whistle up some help and take you back?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: I'll walk back.

lines.speaker: u5639
lines.text: I got to get a lot curiouser than I am--with all them cops out there.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Okay. I be back a little later.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: They was some cops here, Ma. They was takin' down the license numbers. It looks like somebody knows sump'n.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: It had to come, I reckon, soon or later.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: I'd like to stay. I'd like to be with ya--  --an' see your face when you an' Pa get settled in a nice little place. I sure wish I could see you then. But--  --I guess I won't never be able to do that. Not now.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: I could hide you, Tommy.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: I know you would, Ma. But I ain't gonna let you. You hide somebody that's kilt a man an'... an' you'd be in trouble too.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: Awright, Tommy. What you figger you gonna do?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: You know what I been thinkin' about, Ma? About Casy. About what he said, what he done, an' about how he died. An' I remember all of it.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: He was a good man.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: I been thinkin' about us, too--about our people livin' like pigs, an' good rich lan' layin' fallow, or maybe one fella with a million acres, while a hundred thousan' farmers is starvin'. An' I been wonderin' if all our folks got together an' yelled--

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: Tommy, they'll drive you, an' cut you down like they done to Casy.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: They gonna drive me anyways. Soon or later they'll get me, for one thing if not another. Until then...

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: You don't aim to kill nobody, Tom!

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: No, Ma. Not that. That ain't it. But long as I'm a outlaw, anyways, maybe I can do sump'n. Maybe I can jus' fin' out sump'n. Jus' scrounge aroun' an' try to fin' out what it is that's wrong, an then see if they ain't sump'n could be done about it.  But I ain't thought it out clear, Ma. I can't. I don't know enough.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: How'm I gonna know 'bout you? They might kill you an' I wouldn't know. They might hurt you. How'm I gonna know?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Well, maybe it's like Casy says, a fella ain't got a soul of his own, but on'y a piece of a big soul--the one big soul that belongs to ever'body-- an' then...

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: Then what, Tom?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Then it don't matter. Then I'll be all aroun' in the dark. I'll be ever'where--wherever you look. Wherever there's a fight so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. Wherever there's a cop beatin' up a guy, I'll be there. I'll be in the way guys yell when they're mad--an' I'll be in the way kids laugh when they're hungry an' they know supper's ready. An' when our people eat the stuff they raise, an' live in the houses they build, why, I'll be there too.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: I don't understan' it, Tom.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Me neither.  It's jus' stuff I been thinkin' about. Gimme you han', Ma. Good-by.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: Good-by, Tom. Later--when it's blowed over--you'll come back? You'll try to fin' us?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Sure. Good-by.

lines.speaker: u5640
lines.text: Good-by, Tommy.

lines.speaker: u5641
lines.text: Oh, them? Well, no--them's *two* for a penny.

lines.speaker: u5644
lines.text: Well, give me two then, ma'am.

lines.speaker: u5643
lines.text: Then who *do* we shoot?

lines.speaker: u5650
lines.text: Brother, I don't know. If I did I'd tell you. But I just don't know *who's* to blame!

lines.speaker: u5643
lines.text: Well, I'm right here to tell you, mister, ain't *nobody* going to push me off *my* land! Grampa took up this land seventy years ago. My pa was born here. We was *all* born on it, and some of us got killed on it, and some died on it. And that's what makes it ourn--bein' born on it, and workin' it, and dyin' on it--and not no piece of paper with writin' on it! So just come on and try to push me off!

lines.speaker: u5644
lines.text: But what does *that* prove?

lines.speaker: u5648
lines.text: Look at 'em! Same yella han'bill-- 800 pickers wanted. Awright, this man wants 800 men. So he prints up 5,000 a them han'bills an' maybe 20,000 people sees 'em. An' maybe two-three thousan' starts movin, wes' account a this han'bill. Two- three thousan' folks that's crazy with worry headin' out for 800 jobs! Does that make sense?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Cut it out, Pa. He'p Al with the truck.  Don't fret, honey. You goin' to be awright.

lines.speaker: u5645
lines.text: Tom, I jus' don't feel like nothin' a tall. Without him I jus' don't wanta live.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Maybe he'll be back. We'll leave word for him. Jus' don't cry.

lines.speaker: u5653
lines.text: Lemme go! I didn't go to do it!

lines.speaker: u5646
lines.text: Keep qui'te, will ya! Shet your mouth!

lines.speaker: u5653
lines.text: I never knowed it! All I done was pull that string!

lines.speaker: u5646
lines.text: Lissen. You done busted it. You hear?  But lissen here. I won't tell nobody, y'understan'?

lines.speaker: u5653
lines.text: Please don't.

lines.speaker: u5646
lines.text: I won't--  --if you won't tell what *I* done!

lines.speaker: u5647
lines.text: Now you done it! You busted it!

lines.speaker: u5654
lines.text: I never--

lines.speaker: u5649
lines.text: Morning.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Morning.

lines.speaker: u5649
lines.text: You people looking for work?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Mister, we're lookin' even under boards for work.

lines.speaker: u5649
lines.text: Can you pick peaches?

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: We can pick anything.

lines.speaker: u5649
lines.text: Well, there's plenty of work for you about forty miles north, this road just outside Pixley. Turn east on 32 and look for Hooper's ranch. Tell 'em Spencer sent you.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Yes, sir.

lines.speaker: u5651
lines.text: Awright. An' if she gets outa han', I'll be in the right han' corner, this side the dance floor.

lines.speaker: u5652
lines.text: Ain't gonna get outa han'.

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: You do not.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Yes I do.

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: You don't...

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: In the corporate offices.

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: Oh... really?

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Yeah...

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: What do you do?

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: I sell biscuits to the Southland.

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: You do not.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: It's what I do.

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: You're so funny...

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: I sell biscuits and gravy all over the Southland--

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: --Stop it--

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: You know those horsey biscuit gravy packets? I move all of those--

lines.speaker: u5655
lines.text: --No.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Sometimes we sell them to McDonald's and just change them to special barbecue sauce.

lines.speaker: u5656
lines.text: We had pictures put on, that way everybody knows who everybody was!

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Wonderful.

lines.speaker: u5656
lines.text: So, what are you doing now?

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Whatever I can get away with.

lines.speaker: u5657
lines.text: What am I gonna do?

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: What do you want to do?

lines.speaker: u5657
lines.text: I want to be an actor.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Then express yourself, Bob.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Oh I see. You got your individual slices of hope, dignity, confidence, self-love, justice, and harmony.

lines.speaker: u5658
lines.text: You open 'em up and there's the sayings, stories, little bites of insight. It's the P.P.P. Six Day Week.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: So you eat-- read it everyday?

lines.speaker: u5658
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: And these pan pizzas have opened up the doors to heaven?

lines.speaker: u5658
lines.text: Correct.  That's for you. Keep it.

lines.speaker: u5661
lines.text: You kill people.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: I have no illusions about the future. What is, is. We make choices. And we become the sum total of our choices. I can live with that.

lines.speaker: u5661
lines.text: Other people can't.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: ...I am at home with the me. I am rooted in me, who is on this adventure.

lines.speaker: u5662
lines.text: Take a deep breath and realize, that this is me breathing.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: This is me breating.

lines.speaker: u5663
lines.text: I am part of a network of minds, a group of five people who are all connected, over hundreds, even thousands of miles, through the mind. We can think with each other, think for each other. I can be driving somewhere, sleeping with a woman-- whatever it is-- and at the same time be thinking a thought in someone else's mind, far away. Running someone else's brain.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: Up on the right.

lines.speaker: u5663
lines.text: And when you think of it, it's not so surprising that a small group of people control the whole world, is it?

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: There you go. I left it blank.

lines.speaker: u5664
lines.text: Excellent. Here they come.

lines.speaker: u5665
lines.text: The more things change, the more they Goddamned well stay the same.

lines.speaker: u5668
lines.text: I guess.

lines.speaker: u5666
lines.text: Did you see Blank in there?

lines.speaker: u5670
lines.text: No...

lines.speaker: u5863
lines.text: If you search your heart you know all the good you have done.  Your strength comes from your heart -- because in your heart you know what you are fighting for is good and just.  This room is filled with memories. If you search through them you can find the good -- the difference you have made.  And now, it is for you to make the greatest difference of all. Look in your heart, Conner -- and you will see the good that you have done.

lines.speaker: u5867
lines.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Parker.

lines.speaker: u5860
lines.text: Good afternoon...  ... Shirley.

lines.speaker: u5867
lines.text: Would you like to deposit this in your account?

lines.speaker: u5860
lines.text: No.  The money, please.

lines.speaker: u5867
lines.text: This check is for sixteen thousand dollars.  That's a lot of cash to be carrying around.

lines.speaker: u5860
lines.text: I can take care of myself.

lines.speaker: u5867
lines.text: Alright.  It's going to take a few minutes.  I have to call and verify the funds.

lines.speaker: u5869
lines.text: Wow.  Sure, right away, Chief.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Don't tell anyone what you're doing, not Louise, not the other guys, not the Sheriffs.  You understand me, Larry?

lines.speaker: u5869
lines.text: I guess so.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Fuck guessing.  You keep your mouth shut.

lines.speaker: u5869
lines.text: I will, Chief.  Absolutely.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Get to work.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: You get anything on Smith?

lines.speaker: u5870
lines.text: Chief...it's like none of this exists. I'm sorry.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Keep trying.

lines.speaker: u5873
lines.text: And by doing so, he would've known we have spies in his organization.

lines.speaker: u5871
lines.text: Yes, sir.  But what about the disks?  If the cops end up with the disks, we're gonna see a whole lot of heat.

lines.speaker: u5873
lines.text: I hate that Mickey Mouse bastard.  I hated his father, and I hate Sonny, too. Always with the tan.

lines.speaker: u5871
lines.text: What do you want to do?

lines.speaker: u5873
lines.text: Our people out there, they good people? People in the right place?

lines.speaker: u5871
lines.text: The best.

lines.speaker: u5873
lines.text: Sonny's a fuckup.  If he pulls this off, fine--life goes on.  But if the cops end up with those disks, we cut our losses.

lines.speaker: u5871
lines.text: I understand.

lines.speaker: u5873
lines.text: I want a message sent:  No fuckups allowed.

lines.speaker: u5871
lines.text: I'll make the call.

lines.speaker: u5872
lines.text: What, he's cute?  That's his idea of humor?

lines.speaker: u5876
lines.text: If the Feds get those disks, the East Coast is gonna take a hit, too.  You should let them know.

lines.speaker: u5872
lines.text: No way.  I tell them, that Old Man is gonna handle this from back there.

lines.speaker: u5874
lines.text: You mean he <u>left</u>, as in went out the front door?

lines.speaker: u5886
lines.text: I overheard him with the girl.

lines.speaker: u5874
lines.text: <u>Shit</u>!  That <u>fuck</u>!  Even when I want to turn myself in he screws it up!  Did he take the kids with him?

lines.speaker: u5886
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u5874
lines.text: Jesus, get upstairs and find out!  If he took those kids, we're fucked!

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Is Krupchek an aggressive guy?  Hot- tempered?  Anything like that?

lines.speaker: u5875
lines.text: Keeps to himself, more like.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: You have his address?

lines.speaker: u5875
lines.text: Pretty sure I do.  Yeah, here we go --

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: I gave the other one to the Sheriffs and they're giving it to the <u>real</u> FBI.  This one's a fake.

lines.speaker: u5877
lines.text: You'd better be kidding.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: I'm scared shitless.

lines.speaker: u5878
lines.text: That's okay.  I love you anyway.

lines.speaker: u5879
lines.text: What happened?

lines.speaker: u5881
lines.text: Do you want to go or not?  I'm offering you a way out of here.

lines.speaker: u5879
lines.text: I can't go without Thomas.

lines.speaker: u5881
lines.text: All three of us will go, but we have to move fast.  Mars and Dennis don't know I'm doing this.

lines.speaker: u5879
lines.text: How can we get out?

lines.speaker: u5881
lines.text: Dennis and Mars are in the den.  I'll get your brother, then come back for you. We'll go down the stairs and out the front door, you understand?

lines.speaker: u5879
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u5880
lines.text: What's going on?

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Get in the car.  <u>Now</u>.

lines.speaker: u5882
lines.text: That's enough.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Another minute.  Please --

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Is something wrong with Jane?

lines.speaker: u5883
lines.text: We have a boy on the line.  He says he's Thomas Smith and he's calling from the house.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: It's a crank, Louise.  C'mon, don't waste my time with that!

lines.speaker: u5883
lines.text: His cell number belongs to the Smiths.  I think it's real, Chief.  I think this boy is inside that house.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Did you find Jane and Mandy?

lines.speaker: u5884
lines.text: Could you call me back on your phone? Right away.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: What's wrong with the radio?

lines.speaker: u5884
lines.text: Other people can hear us.  Just call. <u>Please</u>.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Stand by.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Let it go, Captain.

lines.speaker: u5887
lines.text: Goddamned small town bullshit.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Mickey?  Call the state Homicide Bureau. Don't touch anything, just sit back and wait.

lines.speaker: u5888
lines.text: Yes, sir.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: The kids are in here!

lines.speaker: u5889
lines.text: Where's the office?

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Help me, goddamnit, we can get the disks later!

lines.speaker: u5893
lines.text: I guess we each have something the other wants.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: I guess we do.

lines.speaker: u5893
lines.text: My people are good to go.  You know who I mean?

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: Your phony FBI assholes.

lines.speaker: u5893
lines.text: We're almost home, you and me.  Keep your shit together.  This isn't L.A.

lines.speaker: u5891
lines.text: What do you mean by that?

lines.speaker: u5893
lines.text: You don't want another dead child on your conscience.

lines.speaker: u5897
lines.text: Paul, we would like to speak to you in your office.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: We, who is we?

lines.speaker: u5897
lines.text: A delegation.

lines.speaker: u5898
lines.text: Paul...  ...I have to talk to you.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: I'll be back.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Don't be foolish. There's more money to be made here.

lines.speaker: u5899
lines.text: You want to buy anymore cockroaches ask for Captain Naramunju.

lines.speaker: u5900
lines.text: Paul, I need you to buy me a day or two. I don't have the fuel for this convoy. I will have to scrounge it.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: I can't. I have nothing left to bribe with. Can your men at the gate hold out for another day?

lines.speaker: u5900
lines.text: No, Paul, they're afraid. They've demanded to be moved back to headquarters now.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Give me their uniforms. I will put people at the gate, in disguise.

lines.speaker: u5900
lines.text: I wish I could, Paul. Try to hold out.

lines.speaker: u5901
lines.text: You lie.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: If you do not help me, you will stay on that list.

lines.speaker: u5901
lines.text: I committed no war crimes.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Who will tell them? You need me to tell how you helped the hotel. The others who have gone, they blame you for all their misfortune. They say you led the massacres.

lines.speaker: u5901
lines.text: I led no massacres.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: You think they will believe you?

lines.speaker: u5901
lines.text: You will tell them the truth.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: I will do nothing unless you help me now.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Let's go.

lines.speaker: u5902
lines.text: Take the river road back. It is clear.

lines.speaker: u5903
lines.text: The news room has heard that the French and the Belgians are putting together an intervention force.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: When will they be here?

lines.speaker: u5903
lines.text: Very soon.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Thank God.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Are you sure this is the river road?

lines.speaker: u5904
lines.text: I saw the sign.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: This is a Rolex, I can't take it.

lines.speaker: u5905
lines.text: Take it for Christ sake. I wish it was a fucking aeroplane.

lines.speaker: u5906
lines.text: Who did you call?

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Call, sir?

lines.speaker: u5906
lines.text: Don't lie to me. What's your name?

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Rusesabagina. Paul Rusesabagina.

lines.speaker: u5906
lines.text: I will remember that name.  Let's go.

lines.speaker: u5907
lines.text: Show us the manager. He wears a suit.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: They have him in the lobby, go quickly.

lines.speaker: u5908
lines.text: It is dangerous to be here. The radio says this is a nest of cockroaches.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: I need one last favor. Go back and get the twins.

lines.speaker: u5908
lines.text: No, it is impossible. That side of town has been destroyed in the fighting. The children are dead.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: How do you know?

lines.speaker: u5908
lines.text: Everyone is dead there. The dogs eat the bodies in the street. I have to go.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: I will give you my house.

lines.speaker: u5911
lines.text: Moses, Moses Seradungu.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Can I help you?

lines.speaker: u5911
lines.text: I'm looking for Moses Seradungu's room.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: What is his room number?

lines.speaker: u5911
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u5909
lines.text: Go downstairs, I will help you.

lines.speaker: u5918
lines.text: Shouldn't somebody like, stand guard or something -- just in case?

lines.speaker: u5917
lines.text: I'll stay, if it'll ease your mind.

lines.speaker: u5918
lines.text: You sure? You'll be alright by yourself?

lines.speaker: u5918
lines.text: Then what the hell are we doing here?

lines.speaker: u5922
lines.text: How'd you make your guest list, Price: throw darts at a phone book?

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: Evelyn... Get up... NOW!

lines.speaker: u5919
lines.text: Steven??

lines.speaker: u5925
lines.text: ...wow....WOW! Hey, Ms. Jenzen -- ?

lines.speaker: u5920
lines.text: Are you still fucking here??

lines.speaker: u5921
lines.text: Please! Something! Oh-God!

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: Maybe if I --

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: -- hey! Next time give me a couple seconds notice before you wing a gag like that!

lines.speaker: u5926
lines.text: The lockdown thing.

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: I mean, not that it didn't give Evelyn the kind of coronary I had in mind, just...

lines.speaker: u5926
lines.text: -- it wasn't me.

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: Rewind that.

lines.speaker: u5926
lines.text: I was just sitting here -- it happened. I had nothing to do with it.

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: Then who did??

lines.speaker: u5926
lines.text: No idea. I didn't even know the damn thing still worked!

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: It works.

lines.speaker: u5926
lines.text: Maybe it was just its time to finally fall apart.

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: No. Somehow -- I don't know how -- she did it.

lines.speaker: u5926
lines.text: Pretty amazing feat: all that shit down the basement and your wife's up in the bedroom the whole time.

lines.speaker: u5923
lines.text: Don't take your eyes off her for a second. I think she just declared War.

lines.speaker: u5924
lines.text: -- ten.

lines.speaker: u5927
lines.text: Please.....anyone....help me?

lines.speaker: u5925
lines.text: Melissa...?

lines.speaker: u5927
lines.text: For the love of God....please...?

lines.speaker: u5925
lines.text: Melissa, it's Sara -- is that you?

lines.speaker: u5927
lines.text: Sara...?

lines.speaker: u5925
lines.text: Keep talking, I'll find you!

lines.speaker: u5927
lines.text: Something....happened --

lines.speaker: u5925
lines.text: -- I'm coming --

lines.speaker: u5927
lines.text: -- something horrible...I don't understand --

lines.speaker: u5928
lines.text: What do these ingredients mean?

lines.speaker: u5931
lines.text: Pearl, is the twilight, the divinity... Onyx is the sickle, death...

lines.speaker: u5929
lines.text: Mommy!

lines.speaker: u5933
lines.text: Aubrey run! Aubrey stares in horror at Maura - just then the knife FADES AWAY as Maura rolls over, returned to normal -

lines.speaker: u5931
lines.text: She's coming back.  Keep talking!

lines.speaker: u5930
lines.text: Come back to us honey!

lines.speaker: u5931
lines.text: Well, you know where to reach me. The church is a stone's throw away if you want to come to mass.

lines.speaker: u5933
lines.text: We'll be there.

lines.speaker: u5932
lines.text: There's something in there.

lines.speaker: u5933
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u5932
lines.text: There's something through that wall!

lines.speaker: u5933
lines.text: Well what is it!

lines.speaker: u5932
lines.text: I don't know!  Trust what I'm saying, we have to open this wall!

lines.speaker: u5934
lines.text: Not on station time.

lines.speaker: u5937
lines.text: No.  Not on station time.  My story.  My time.

lines.speaker: u5937
lines.text: Hello?

lines.speaker: u5935
lines.text: You wanted a story.  You got it.  Turn on the TV now.  And then get your ass down here ...  ...

lines.speaker: u5937
lines.text: Doc?  ...  Doc ... Hello?

lines.speaker: u5936
lines.text: The Box, Joey.  He wants the Box.

lines.speaker: u5939
lines.text: Never mind.  I'm glad it's gone.  Made the store feel strange.  Who'd make such a thing?

lines.speaker: u5937
lines.text: Fine.  Fine.  But can you tell us anything about it?

lines.speaker: u5939
lines.text: It was part of a job-lot.  Some loony- bin they shut down.  Unclaimed stuff.

lines.speaker: u5937
lines.text: What else came with it?  Anything still here?

lines.speaker: u5939
lines.text: Sure.  Just papers, photos.  Stuff nobody'd ever want.

lines.speaker: u5937
lines.text: Can we see?

lines.speaker: u5939
lines.text: You gonna buy?

lines.speaker: u5937
lines.text: I don't know.  Maybe.

lines.speaker: u5939
lines.text: Right at the back there.  Middle shelves.  Coupla folders.  Nice stuff. I'd do you a good price.

lines.speaker: u5942
lines.text: Really?

lines.speaker: u5938
lines.text: Yes!  God, yes.  I ... I just want to hug you.  To hold you.  To tell you it's alright.

lines.speaker: u5943
lines.text: Get 'em.  They went down the hallway.

lines.speaker: u5951
lines.text: Let's just forget it, I mean...

lines.speaker: u5943
lines.text: Get em....

lines.speaker: u5944
lines.text: How.

lines.speaker: u5951
lines.text: You're unemployed, Alfie.  Boss is dead.  Her plan is over.

lines.speaker: u5944
lines.text: My plan is just beginning.  I'll forgive you for denying me the pleasure of slaughtering my boorish employers, but I'm afraid the birth of the new British Empire can have no witnesses!

lines.speaker: u5951
lines.text: Ooh-kay...

lines.speaker: u5945
lines.text: What the hell....

lines.speaker: u5954
lines.text: You're supposed to be dead!

lines.speaker: u5946
lines.text: Cat got his tongue?

lines.speaker: u5952
lines.text: Actually he never told us what it was.

lines.speaker: u5948
lines.text: Good job, not pretty, but good.

lines.speaker: u5951
lines.text: Ah, the mafia, the cops; do I know how to party or what?

lines.speaker: u5949
lines.text: What a pleasant surprise.  You're probably wondering...

lines.speaker: u5951
lines.text: But you're going to tell us anyway...

lines.speaker: u5950
lines.text: All this trouble for a horsey. I may not know art, but I know what I like.

lines.speaker: u5951
lines.text: You certainly do.

lines.speaker: u5950
lines.text: So when's that Sebastian-Cabot- Buckingham-Palace-looking- Butlerhead getting here?

lines.speaker: u5951
lines.text: Why does this have to be so hard...

lines.speaker: u5952
lines.text: Tell me about it...

lines.speaker: u5955
lines.text: The Hoopsucker!

lines.speaker: u5956
lines.text: The Hudswinger!

lines.speaker: u5955
lines.text: The Hoop-dee-doo!

lines.speaker: u5956
lines.text: The Hudsucker Hoop!

lines.speaker: u5957
lines.text: Nobody told me! Nobody told me! You sold all of our stock?

lines.speaker: u5970
lines.text: We dumped the whole load. Now quit showboating, Addison --

lines.speaker: u5957
lines.text: I had twenty thousand shares! I'd be a millionaire now!

lines.speaker: u5970
lines.text: Sure, sure, we'd all be millionaires. There's no point in looking back. At the time, Stilson thought dumping our position would panic the market, further depress the stock -- then we'd buy it all back, and more of course, once it got cheap --

lines.speaker: u5957
lines.text: Cheap! Cheap! It's never been more valuable! And I'm ruined! Ruined!

lines.speaker: u5963
lines.text: Whatever! It's no dig on you, Archer, but this story is hot and you're no longer on top of it. Why, it's the scoop of the century -- the other papers won't have the Gunderson dope 'til tomorrow -- The Allemeinischer Zeitung, Le Figaro, they'll be choking on our dust come mornin' --

lines.speaker: u5958
lines.text: You're fools, both of you! It's obvious they're out to crucify Norville! They're trying to destroy him!

lines.speaker: u5963
lines.text: Amy -- take a break. You've worked hard on this story -- heck, you broke it for us! But it's passed you by and Smith here has taken up the slack.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: How long've you been down here?

lines.speaker: u5959
lines.text: Forty-eight years...

lines.speaker: u5960
lines.text: Yeah, daddy, that's a roger, but we don't sell alcohol.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: What kind of bar is it if ya can't get a martini?!

lines.speaker: u5960
lines.text: It's a juice and coffee bar, man, like I been tellin' ya --

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: I want a martini! On this bar, right now! I've had a martini in every bar on the way down here, and I'm not about to --

lines.speaker: u5960
lines.text: Martinis are for squares, man.

lines.speaker: u5961
lines.text: ...It's the most beautiful t'ing I ever saw.

lines.speaker: u5967
lines.text: It's the most beautiful t'ing I ever saw.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: ...You don't?

lines.speaker: u5962
lines.text: Nah, that's all forgotten.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: ...It is?

lines.speaker: u5962
lines.text: Sure, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid said I could have the job back.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: Absolutely, Buzz, I'm glad he --

lines.speaker: u5962
lines.text: But he told me you stole that swell hoop idea from me. What gives!

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: But, Buzz --

lines.speaker: u5962
lines.text: Say, that was a swell idea!

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: But, Buzz, you know I never --

lines.speaker: u5962
lines.text: And Sid says you stole it!

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: But Buzz --

lines.speaker: u5965
lines.text: ...Yeah, go ahead.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: '...But Sid, let me urge you to work closely with the new president, and to keep giving Hudsucker Industries all your energies -- but not your soul. For while we must strive for success, we must not worship it. Long live the Hud. Waring Hudsucker...'

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: ...Well, I'm not sure where I --

lines.speaker: u5966
lines.text: I need that voucher! I told you a week ago it was important!

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: But look, I'm president of the company now and I --

lines.speaker: u5966
lines.text: I don't care if you're president of the company! I need that voucher! Now!

lines.speaker: u5969
lines.text: Well, frankly, I...

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: You have a charming wife, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: Sorry I'm late, Sid. That back nine at Riverdale is really murder.

lines.speaker: u5970
lines.text: Sure, sure, it's a tough course. Well thanks for coming, kid. I thought the board room would be a swell place to chat undisturbed -- it seems we're having some security problems here at the Hud.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: Ya don't say.

lines.speaker: u5970
lines.text: Mm. Ordinarily I wouldn't bother you with it, but -- this is embarrassing, kid -- it seems to concern you directly.

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: How's that, Sid?

lines.speaker: u5970
lines.text: It's not important in itself -- some elevator boy you fired came to me claiming you'd stolen the idea for the, uh, the hoop dingus from him --

lines.speaker: u5971
lines.text: Huh?! He -- no, I -- he's just -- maybe I was a little rough on the boy, ya see I --

lines.speaker: u5970
lines.text: Ah forget it, kid, ya don't have to explain to me. He's a little person. He's nothing. Like I say, ordinarily it would just be a nuisance. But it seems -- well, there was a spy in the company...

lines.speaker: u5973
lines.text: She's good, Bennie.

lines.speaker: u5974
lines.text: She's damn good, Lou.

lines.speaker: u5975
lines.text: Things so bad, nobody can help -- not even Doctor Maxwell.

lines.speaker: u5976
lines.text: Doctors and nurses can only do so much, Alma.  They can't cure everything.

lines.speaker: u5975
lines.text: Doctors that are people can't cure everything.

lines.speaker: u5976
lines.text: What do you mean -- "doctors that are people"?

lines.speaker: u5975
lines.text: There are other doctors...Yes, other doctors...Better doctors...

lines.speaker: u5976
lines.text: Where?

lines.speaker: u5975
lines.text: At the Houmfort.

lines.speaker: u5976
lines.text: That's nonsense, Alma.

lines.speaker: u5975
lines.text: They even cure nonsense, Miss Betsy.  Mama Rose was mindless.  I was at the Houmfort when the Houngan brought her mind back.

lines.speaker: u5976
lines.text: You mean Mama Rose was like Mrs. Holland?

lines.speaker: u5975
lines.text: No.  She was mindless but not like Miss Jessica.  But the Houngan cured her.

lines.speaker: u5976
lines.text: Are you trying to tell me that the Houngan -- the voodoo priest -- could cure Mrs. Holland?

lines.speaker: u5975
lines.text: Yes, Miss Betsy.  I mean that.  The Houngan will speak to the rada drums and the drums will speak to Shango and Damballa.

lines.speaker: u5979
lines.text: Considering that the paper is three months old and this isn't Sunday -- no thank you.

lines.speaker: u5976
lines.text: I guess I'll wait until I'm home, Mrs. Rand.

lines.speaker: u5979
lines.text: Dr. Maxwell is right, Mother.

lines.speaker: u5978

lines.text: We need fertilizer, Winston.

lines.speaker: u6321
lines.text: We also need a fucking money counter, William! We have to get the money out by Thursday and I'll be buggered if I am counting it . . . and if you have to get your sodding fertilizer, couldn't you be a little more subtle?

lines.speaker: u6320
lines.text: What do you mean?

lines.speaker: u6321
lines.text: I mean we grow copious amounts of ganja, and you don't look like your average hort-er-fucking-culturalist, that's what I mean, Willy.

lines.speaker: u6322
lines.text: It's my life. If I want to fuck it up, that's my business.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: I said pretty much the same thing to my mother when I was your age.

lines.speaker: u6322
lines.text: And what did she do?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Two years at hard labor, Our Lady of Perpetual Help.

lines.speaker: u6322
lines.text: Catholic school, nasty.

lines.speaker: u6348
lines.text: Private Johnson!

lines.speaker: u6323
lines.text: Sergeant?

lines.speaker: u6348
lines.text: Report to Dr. Innis at the clinic.

lines.speaker: u6323
lines.text: I'm feeling okay--

lines.speaker: u6348
lines.text: I'm very happy to hear that, Private. Now you go put some pee-pee in a cup for Dr. Innis and I'll be feeling okay, too.

lines.speaker: u6323
lines.text: You're testing me?

lines.speaker: u6348
lines.text: You and one hundred nineteen other fortunate individuals. Put it in gear.

lines.speaker: u6323
lines.text: Yes, Sergeant.

lines.speaker: u6324
lines.text: You uhm--you remember what old Buddy carried for a side arm?

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Colt Peacemaker.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: He swore by it.  What?

lines.speaker: u6324
lines.text: Just wondering.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: So is Buddy on your short list?

lines.speaker: u6324
lines.text: If it was some poor mojado, swam across at night, got lost in the scrub and starved out there, we wouldn't go any further. But this is a formerly prominent citizen.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: You got to investigate. No question about it.

lines.speaker: u6324
lines.text: What I will do is keep names out of it till we got some answers or hit a dead end. You know how the press is with a murder story--even if it's forty years old.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Yeah, it's a pretty cold trail.

lines.speaker: u6325
lines.text: Whole different story; isn't it?

lines.speaker: u6353
lines.text: You're fired. You're outta the department.

lines.speaker: u6325
lines.text: There's not a soul in this county isn't sick to death of your bullshit, Charley. You made yourself scarce, you could make a lot of people happy.

lines.speaker: u6353
lines.text: You little pissant--

lines.speaker: u6325
lines.text: Now or later, Charley. You won't have any trouble finding me.

lines.speaker: u6326
lines.text: 350 pounds.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u6326
lines.text: This boy from West Side, plays tackle both ways. Bench-presses 350 pounds. You imagine having that much weight on top of you? Pushing down? Be hard to breathe. Hard to swallow.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: I think they have another fella there to keep it off your chest. A spotter.

lines.speaker: u6326
lines.text: "I only got my little girl now," he says, "she's my lifeline." Then he tells me I can't be in the box anymore if I can't control myself. Sonofabitch don't even watch the damn game, just sits there drinking with his bidness friends, look up at the TV now and then. I do better to sit in the cheap seats with some real football people.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: You look good, Bunny. It's nice to see you.

lines.speaker: u6326
lines.text: Thanks. I like it when you say that, Sam.

lines.speaker: u6332
lines.text: Where'd he get all this?

lines.speaker: u6327
lines.text: Your mother got a brother--Alphonse--

lines.speaker: u6332
lines.text: Uncle Al--

lines.speaker: u6327
lines.text: Otis stood on good terms with the man. Whenever you do something makes the news, he sends it on. When they made you General, Otis just about drove away all our customers going on about it.

lines.speaker: u6332
lines.text: I'm a colonel.

lines.speaker: u6327
lines.text: Yeah, I know--Man made me memorize the whole damn Army chain of command before he'd marry me. So this is a big deal, commander and  all?

lines.speaker: u6332
lines.text: It's a small post and they're phasing it out in two years, but I moved up in rank and--well, a command is a command.

lines.speaker: u6327
lines.text: Otis went on like you were that guy who won the Gulf War. Colin whatsit.

lines.speaker: u6332
lines.text: My mother said he never asked about--

lines.speaker: u6327
lines.text: He never asked her.

lines.speaker: u6332
lines.text: Maybe we'll clean that thing out back up, have a barbecue next weekend. We could invite him and his wife over.

lines.speaker: u6328
lines.text: Cool.

lines.speaker: u6329
lines.text: Bird flying south-you think he sees that line? Rattlesnake, javelina-- whatever you got--halfway across that line they don't start thinking different. So why should a man?

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Your government always been pretty happy to have that line. The question's just been where to draw it

lines.speaker: u6329
lines.text: My government can go fuck itself, and so can yours. I'm talking about people here--men. Mi amigo Eladio Cruz is giving some friends of his a lift in his camion one day--

lines.speaker: u6330
lines.text: Sheriff--hi--this is Sergeant--this is Priscilla Worth.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Pleased to meet you.

lines.speaker: u6330
lines.text: Sheriff Deeds was in on our archeological find yesterday.

lines.speaker: u6331
lines.text: --warning. Not 'cause he had it in for the colored

lines.speaker: u6331
lines.text: --but just as a kind of safety tip.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Yeah. I bet he would.

lines.speaker: u6331
lines.text: Old Sam stood for somethin', you know? The day that man died they broke the goddamn mold.

lines.speaker: u6344
lines.text: I gonna meet that family of yours?

lines.speaker: u6332
lines.text: Why would you want to do that?

lines.speaker: u6344
lines.text: Because I'm your father.

lines.speaker: u6333
lines.text: Como se llama? [What's your name?]

lines.speaker: u6355
lines.text: Mercedes Gonzales Ruiz.

lines.speaker: u6333
lines.text: Me llama Eladio Cruz--Bienvenido a Tejas. [Welcome to Texas.]

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: Rapidamente! Everybody in the world is going to see!

lines.speaker: u6334
lines.text: Donde vamos? [Where are we going?]

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: A casa de Porfirio Zayas. He used to be a doctor on the other side. Gunshot wounds, fixing babies--if you can pay he can handle it.

lines.speaker: u6334
lines.text: Senora, anything it costs, I can work--

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: Don't worry about it. He owes me some favors.

lines.speaker: u6335
lines.text: Your mother was a saint.

lines.speaker: u6337
lines.text: --but Buddy Deeds was my salvation.

lines.speaker: u6336
lines.text: When we backed you--

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: When you backed me you needed somebody named Deeds to bump the other fella out of office.  Hey, folks--

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Don't think the Rangers are likely to find out any more than they already have.

lines.speaker: u6337
lines.text: Word gets out who that body was, people are gonna think Buddy done it.

lines.speaker: u6338
lines.text: There isn't money allocated for that. But a jail--

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Look, I'm not gonna campaign against your deal here, but if anybody asks me, I got to tell them the truth. We-- don't--need--a new jail.

lines.speaker: u6339
lines.text: Steve called for you.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Steve?

lines.speaker: u6339
lines.text: Steve. Board of Education Steve who likes you? He goes for us hot-blooded Mexican girls, I can tell.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Spanish, please. My mother would have a heart attack.

lines.speaker: u6339
lines.text: Your mother's family is Spanish?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Sure, they go back to Cortez. When he rode by, they were squatting in a hut cooking hamsters for dinner.

lines.speaker: u6339
lines.text: You got to be interested in somebody. All you do is work.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: All my mother does is work. That's how you get to be Spanish.

lines.speaker: u6339
lines.text: How 'bout the Sheriff?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: The Sheriff.

lines.speaker: u6339
lines.text: The old-high-school-heartthrob Sheriff. I thought you were crazy about each other. He's available, you're available--

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: I'm unmarried. I'm not available.

lines.speaker: u6339
lines.text: You told me one time it was true love.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: There must have been somebody.

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: I was too busy.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Nobody's too busy.

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: Maybe now. It was different back then. I had this place, I was doing all the shopping, all the cooking. What do I need some chulo with grease under his nails to drink up the profit?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: I don't mean Fernando.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Mami, the first time I brought him home, those were your exact words-- "some chulo with grease under his nails."

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: I never said that.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: You made it pretty damn clear you thought he was nobody.

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: I felt that you could do better for yourself--

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: What? Become a nun? You didn't want me going out with Anglos--

lines.speaker: u6340
lines.text: I never said that. It was just that boy--

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: "That boy"--Mami, say his name for chrissakes!

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Mrs. Bledsoe?

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: That's me.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: I'm Sheriff Deeds--

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Sheriff Deeds' dead, honey--you just Sheriff junior.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Yeah, that's the story of my life.

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: You ever play one of these?

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: I've seen 'em.

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Well, don't ever start up on 'em, cause once you do you can't stop. I tell myself I'm gonna play just three little games after breakfast, and here I sit with half the day gone.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: You mind if I ask a few questions about your husband? Roderick?

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: I won't say nothing bad about the man, but you can ask away.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: He had the club out on the old trail road--

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: We run that twenty-odd years. Give it over to Otis Payne in 1967. April.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: So you must remember Sheriff Wade.

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Not if I can help it.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: You had to deal with him in running the club.

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Them days, you deal with Sheriff Wade or you didn't deal at all. First of the month, every month, he remind you of who you really workin' for.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: He squeezed money out of you?

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Wasn't legal to sell liquor in a glass back then unless you was a club, see. Roderick used to say, "Buy yourself a drink, you get a free membership." But Sheriff Wade, he could shut you down anytime.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: And my father?

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Sheriff Buddy was a different story. Long as Roderick throw his weight the right way on election day, make sure all the colored get out to vote- we was called colored back then, if you was polite--maybe throw a barbecue for the right people now and then, things was peaceful. That Sheriff Wade, though, he took an awful big bite.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: People didn't complain?

lines.speaker: u6342
lines.text: Not if they was colored or Meskin. Not if they wanted to keep breathin'.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Do you remember the last time you saw him?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: I don't think you can take it personally--

lines.speaker: u6343
lines.text: I'd like to see them spend a day pulling 14-year-olds off of each other--I should get combat pay--

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: I have new respect for some of my kids, meeting the parents they've been dealt--

lines.speaker: u6344
lines.text: I'm not open. We were just talking.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Hollis probably told you we found Charley Wade.

lines.speaker: u6344
lines.text: Yeah. How about that? People start digging holes in this county, there's no telling what'll come up.

lines.speaker: u6345
lines.text: Can I get this?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Nobody really wears that stuff, Paloma.

lines.speaker: u6345
lines.text: I could name five girls at school who have one just like it--

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Enough with the clothes--

lines.speaker: u6345
lines.text: Just 'cause you went to Catholic school and wore a uniform.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: I only went for my last two years.

lines.speaker: u6345
lines.text: How come?

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Oh, my mother wanted to keep me away from away from boys.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: You built our patio while you  were on the county?

lines.speaker: u6346
lines.text: Out in the fresh air, nice gringo lady making you pies--who's gonna sit back in a little jail cell all day? Sheriff Buddy, man. Como el no hay dos. And after that cabron Charley Wade--

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: I've heard Wade was a bit tough on the Mexicans--

lines.speaker: u6346
lines.text: He murdered Eladio Cruz. That tough enough for you?

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Murdered him?

lines.speaker: u6346
lines.text: Chucho Montoya saw it with his own eyes. Shot him in cold blood.

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: We start from scratch--

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Yeah--

lines.speaker: u6347
lines.text: Everything that went before, all that stuff, that history--the hell with it, right?

lines.speaker: u6352
lines.text: You're the one who's a good boy. Man say "fetch" and you fetch--

lines.speaker: u6349
lines.text: Just doing my job.

lines.speaker: u6352
lines.text: White man just using you to keep the Black man down.

lines.speaker: u6349
lines.text: This isn't Houston, my friend. We pretty much running things now. Our good day has come.

lines.speaker: u6352
lines.text: You suckers haven't had a good day since the Alamo.

lines.speaker: u6353
lines.text: What's this I see? Is that whiskey in them glasses on the Bar? Roderick, I'm gonna have to cite you for a violation of state law--

lines.speaker: u6350
lines.text: This is a club, Sheriff--you been in here--

lines.speaker: u6353
lines.text: And people better clear out of here! Now!

lines.speaker: u6354
lines.text: If he hadn't found that Deputy job, I believe Buddy might've gone down the other path, got into some serious trouble. Settled him right down. That and your mother. 'Course he had that other one later.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: Another woman?

lines.speaker: u6354
lines.text: Your mother wasn't one to get chased off her patch. Half the damn county knew and nobody thought the worse of her for seein' it through.

lines.speaker: u6351
lines.text: You know who it was?

lines.speaker: u6354
lines.text: The other one? Hell, at my age, every time you learn a new name you got to forget an old one. Your head's all crowded up--here it is--

lines.speaker: u6353
lines.text: How come you don't took familiar?

lines.speaker: u6356
lines.text: Been away. Up to Houston.

lines.speaker: u6353
lines.text: Houston, huh? I hear they let you boys run wild up there.

lines.speaker: u6357
lines.text: It's supposed to be some big sin, even if you love each other.

lines.speaker: u6358
lines.text: You believe that?

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: Hello, L.A.

lines.speaker: u6360
lines.text: Have a nice evening, Mr. D'Amour.

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: You bet.

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: Thanks, Billy.

lines.speaker: u6361
lines.text: Hey, anytime.  Actually, no.  This was enough.

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: Right.

lines.speaker: u6362
lines.text: That's so cool.

lines.speaker: u6372
lines.text: Please... I wasn't there... Ask Pimm.

lines.speaker: u6363
lines.text: Pimm's dead.  Jennifer Desiderio's disappeared...

lines.speaker: u6373
lines.text: I'm putting in a new illusion tonight.  Will you be there?

lines.speaker: u6365
lines.text: Sure.  You want me to find out about Quaid?  I mean, the funeral?

lines.speaker: u6373
lines.text: No.  I'm not going near him.

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: Are you finished with me?

lines.speaker: u6366
lines.text: For now.  Are you planning to go back to New York?

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: No.  Not yet...

lines.speaker: u6368
lines.text: Nix! Nix!

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: Is he the Puritan?

lines.speaker: u6368
lines.text: Yes! Yes!

lines.speaker: u6367
lines.text: And he's dead?

lines.speaker: u6368
lines.text: No.  He's coming back.  He's digging his way out!

lines.speaker: u6371
lines.text: Wait... you still feel something for that bitch?

lines.speaker: u6373
lines.text: No!

lines.speaker: u6371
lines.text: Liar!

lines.speaker: u6385
lines.text: Hello? Yes?

lines.speaker: u6378
lines.text: Hello, can I have room 5601.

lines.speaker: u6385
lines.text: One moment.

lines.speaker: u6379
lines.text: Oh, it's nothing... I better go, I'll talk to you later.

lines.speaker: u6383
lines.text: Ok, have fun there, you're so lucky you don't have any kids yet and you can go off to Japan... call me when you get back.

lines.speaker: u6379
lines.text: Ok, bye.

lines.speaker: u6381
lines.text: Oh no...

lines.speaker: u6382
lines.text: ...Well, I have the worst  headache, I have to go find some aspirin. But, call me, let's have a drink, I'm under Evelyn Waugh.

lines.speaker: u6387
lines.text: You know, I made a reservation at Marco's for Peter's birthday dinner, but maybe you should cater it.

lines.speaker: u6391
lines.text: What time did you make it for?

lines.speaker: u6387
lines.text: Eight.  That okay?

lines.speaker: u6403
lines.text: I can take care of myself.

lines.speaker: u6388
lines.text: I'm gonna go make a stink.  Sit tight. I'll make sure you get a change of clothes.

lines.speaker: u6389
lines.text: The patient was in great distress. Naturally he was...yelling.

lines.speaker: u6393
lines.text: And was he in distress when you opened the door?  Or was he sitting here, relaxed, at this table?

lines.speaker: u6389
lines.text: There is a medical explanation for everything that happened.

lines.speaker: u6393
lines.text: You heard voices, you know you did.

lines.speaker: u6393
lines.text: You'll do it?

lines.speaker: u6390
lines.text: I don't have the experience.  Father Thomas should officiate.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: You fucking bastard.

lines.speaker: u6391
lines.text: Don't you get it?  They had their 2,000 years.  Now it's our turn.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: So all that bullshit about God and faith.

lines.speaker: u6391
lines.text: It was perfect.  The harder I pushed, the more you pulled away.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: You lied to me my whole life. Everything you said, everything you did.

lines.speaker: u6391
lines.text: Everything I did, I did for you.  I love you, Peter.  Think of it.  I'm giving you a gift, absolute power and knowledge.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: You raised me, like a son.

lines.speaker: u6391
lines.text: You are my son.  Don't you see the opportunity that lies before you?

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: You killed my parents.

lines.speaker: u6391
lines.text: I had to.  There was no other way. Their deaths were part of the greatest legacy I could have given you.

lines.speaker: u6393
lines.text: Father, please don't die.

lines.speaker: u6392
lines.text: ...art sank, sun set, ark sank again...

lines.speaker: u6402
lines.text: You don't want to face it.

lines.speaker: u6393
lines.text: Look, John, I'm facing it.

lines.speaker: u6402
lines.text: I'm not waiting until it's too late.

lines.speaker: u6394
lines.text: You do know, don't you.  That these are also numbers.  Greek numbers, 600, 60 and 6 - or 666.  The sign of the Devil.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: Get out of here.

lines.speaker: u6394
lines.text: Goodbye.

lines.speaker: u6395
lines.text: Mr. Kelson, here's the stuff you wanted on pathological narcissism.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: What about that psychic, what's his name, Szabo?

lines.speaker: u6395
lines.text: He can see you Thursday.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: I think it's gonna be a waste of time.

lines.speaker: u6395
lines.text: The police used him as a witness in this case.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: I'll be at Bedford tonight, if you need me.

lines.speaker: u6395
lines.text: Nice suit.

lines.speaker: u6397
lines.text: Good of you to stop by.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: We millionaires yet?

lines.speaker: u6401
lines.text: We hauled her in earlier but didn't have anything hard to tie her to Townsend. Far as the priest goes, he won't be bothering you.  Suffered a complete mental breakdown, during - get this - during an exorcism.

lines.speaker: u6398
lines.text: Where is she now?

lines.speaker: u6401
lines.text: Had to let her go.  I see you thinkin' there, superstar. Don't.

lines.speaker: u6412
lines.text: You know, girl, long as I've lived next door, I've never seen the inside of this house.

lines.speaker: u6404
lines.text: Really?  Well, come on, then.

lines.speaker: u6405
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u6410
lines.text: It's just...it seems like you're always yelling at me.

lines.speaker: u6405
lines.text: You think I'd go hoarse for a player with no potential?   When I ignore you, that's when you worry.  Go get dressed.

lines.speaker: u6410
lines.text: Wait...

lines.speaker: u6406
lines.text: Shh.  It's okay.

lines.speaker: u6407
lines.text: Quincy, word has it you might make the jump the NBA.

lines.speaker: u6416
lines.text: Don't go starting rumors, Jim.  My son's college bound with or without basketball.

lines.speaker: u6407
lines.text: You could make a career by telling me where.

lines.speaker: u6416
lines.text: Gotta wait til the press conference.

lines.speaker: u6407
lines.text: But you'd love for him to play at USC, like you did.

lines.speaker: u6416
lines.text: I'd love for him to get a good education.  That's it.

lines.speaker: u6413
lines.text: Nah.

lines.speaker: u6408
lines.text: Why not?

lines.speaker: u6413
lines.text: You might be the only one with a job.

lines.speaker: u6408
lines.text: Baby, don't talk like that.  Your rehab's going well.  You'll be back before you know it.

lines.speaker: u6413
lines.text: Sometimes I wonder if it's worth it. Busting my ass, for what?

lines.speaker: u6408
lines.text: To do what you love.

lines.speaker: u6413
lines.text: I don't know sometimes.

lines.speaker: u6408
lines.text: You're just scared.  I know rehab is hard, and you have to worry about whether you'll be as good as you were but you will be.  I believe in you.  You just have to get back on the court.  Like you'd get back on a horse.

lines.speaker: u6413
lines.text: A horse?

lines.speaker: u6408
lines.text: Don't make fun of me when I'm being wonderful and supportive.  You belong on the court.  Just like I belong in the stands, looking cute and cheering you on.

lines.speaker: u6410
lines.text: You ever been in love?

lines.speaker: u6409
lines.text: Too many times.

lines.speaker: u6410
lines.text: They ever love you back?

lines.speaker: u6409
lines.text: Yeah, once I cut them off.  Why?

lines.speaker: u6410
lines.text: Give it yourself.

lines.speaker: u6414
lines.text: I don't wanna look fast.  Thanks, girl.
